body:
### Problem

In `init.vim`, setting `colorscheme vim` ignores other `hi` commands. However, running the same highlight command after start works as expected.



### Steps to reproduce

Loading this file has the line numbers still using the default color
```vim
" ~/.config/nvim/init.vim
set notermguicolors 
colorscheme vim

hi LineNr ctermfg=7
set nu
```

… but manually running `:hi LineNr ctermfg=7` sets the correct colors.

(In this example I use `notermguicolors`, but the result is the same without it, and the highlight rule uses `guifg` instead – it does not get applied on load. Also, I have aliased `vim` to `nvim`, so it actually is Neovim that is being run)

![Kapture 2024-08-14 at 16 15 34](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/39aae996-b987-4e81-b6ba-7f1359561163)


### Expected behavior

I would expect my highlight rules after the `colorscheme vim` to apply, and not have to run them manually.

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

0.10.1 Release

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no, N/A

### Operating system/version

macOS 14.5

### Terminal name/version

iTerm2 3.5.4

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

homebrew

```vim
function! SetHighlights()
  if &background == "dark"
    " on dark background
  elseif &background == "light"

  endif

autocmd ColorScheme * call SetHighlights()
```

Could I please get any acknowledgement of the issue I am experiencing?

> To me, it seems like when Nvim first starts up, it waits until the file has loaded, and then clears the syntax to apply the light legacy Vim color scheme.

Vim sets in most cases `background` to light. Neovim defaults to dark (see `:h background` and `:h nvim-defaults`) so it is possible that when using the default colorscheme with the terminal palette set to light but neovim as `background` set to dark some colors will be scuffed.

Try to forcefully set background to light when using light mode on the mac and see if gets better

```vim
set background=light
colorscheme vim
```

If I got this correctly the only thing you can do to make this automatic is either:
1. use a terminal that supports the specific escape sequence that neovim uses to check whether to use dark or light background (in my case I use wezterm)
2. if you want to still use you current terminal (I think you are using iTerm2) you need to check manually whether or not MacOS is in lightmode and switch the background before the colorscheme is loaded with `ColorSchemePre`

```vim
function s:check_background()
  " NOTE: this can definitely increase your startup time 
  " depending on how much time the command used takes to execute 
  let macos_theme = system(<insert command to check macos apperence>)
  if macos_theme ==# 'light'
    set background=light
  endif
endfunction
autocmd ColorSchemePre * call s:check_background()

" all the color ovverrides and setting colorscheme goes here
```

Another alternative may be some plugins but I'm not sure

> Try to forcefully set background to light […] `set background=light`

I am using iTerm2. Right now I don't have a command to check if in light or dark mode, but I'll see around what my possibilities are.

> Vim sets in most cases background to light. Neovim defaults to dark […] so it is possible that when using the default colorscheme with the terminal palette set to light but neovim as background set to dark some colors will be scuffed.

This is the best explanation I've heard, and indeed works if I set the background manually first. Thanks @saccarosium!

This is a workaround to solve my issue on macOS, such that I can use the default color scheme with my own highlights!

```vim
function s:check_background()
  let macos_theme = system("defaults read -g AppleInterfaceStyle 2>/dev/null")
  if macos_theme ==# ''
    set background=light
  else
    set background=dark
  endif
endfunction
autocmd ColorSchemePre * call s:check_background()

set notermguicolors
colorscheme vim
```

I wish I didn't have to have this snippet in my init file, and this isn't cross platform either, but for now this works for me for now.

If the developers would like to reopen this issue I'd be more than happy. Manually setting the background before running `colorscheme vim` does not clear my syntax highlight that are applied once Neovim opens. I don't know how I'd handle this on my non-macOS machines.

> I wish I didn't have to have this snippet in my init file, and this isn't cross platform either, but for now this works for me for now.

Unfortunately we cannot do that much to make this more cross platform. We have a mechanism to detect this but it is terminal dependent. Terminal applications do not have the same APIs that GUIs have to detect this sort of things. If we create our own it would probably be junky an hassle to maintain.
